With Navan, employees are motivated to save even more.
When booking travel below policy, employees earn Navan rewards toward their next vacation.
It's fully funded by us, so your company keeps all those juicy savings.
Using Navan is a no-brainer. It's free to get started.
So, what's the wait? Start saving today.
The world's smartest corporate card
just teamed up with
the world's best enterprise travel
to deliver BrexPay for Navan.
The new gold standard in enterprise travel.

transcript_segments.text: Business travel is a lot. Endless searches, confusing policies, being trapped on hold.
Fees, receipts, expense reports. Travel shouldn't be a liability, it should be an opportunity.
Enter Navan, the industry's best travel and expense solution. Navan has a singular mission:
make travel easy for every frequent traveler. The magic begins with booking.
Across flights, hotels, trains, and rental cars, Navan's custom-built platform curates an unparalleled global travel inventory.
Then, proprietary AI, backed by a decade of data and fine-tuning, serves up personalized results based on preferences, prior trips, loyalty programs, and more.
With company policies built in, so businesses can save money, track spend, and support their teams.
Navan also rewards smart spending. When travelers choose lower cost hotels, their company gets the savings, and they get credits to use towards a dream vacation,
or to extend a business trip with just a click. Making changes? No problem.
Add luggage, swap seats, or cancel. In the office or on the move.
Need help? Whether you call our world-class agents or chat with our multilingual AI assistant, Navan is there for you 24/7.
Travelers can track their spend against company policies in real time and kick time-consuming expense reports to the curb.
Navan automatically captures and categorizes transactions right away. Tap, spend, done.
Finance and accounting teams can proactively manage spend and leverage actionable insights for smarter budgeting, saving time and money.
When Navan is in your reach, the whole world is within your grasp. Navan: Making travel easy for every frequent traveler.
Our philosophy at Navan is simple: deliver smarter travel and expense management for your business and an experience travelers love.
Today, we're here to show you how our latest release delivers on that promise. This is the Navan Summer 2025 release.

When a business trip ends, the work is often just beginning for finance and accounting teams. Moving data between your T&E platform and accounting system is often a bottleneck that requires manual exports, uploads, and reconciliation.

That's why we've added Sage Intacct to our suite of direct integrations. Now, all transactions flow directly to your ledger, instantly and accurately, ensuring cleaner books and quicker month-end close.

But that's only one part of the equation. The other is ensuring you get the most value from your spend in the first place, and that starts with smarter booking. Our new split ticketing feature for UK rail does exactly that.
It automatically splits a single journey into multiple cheaper tickets. Your traveler's journey is exactly the same, the savings are simply built-in.
Now, smarter booking also means giving travelers more confidence when planning their next trip.
We put on-time performance data front and center in our shopping flow to help you avoid those notoriously late flights and choose a more reliable option.
When booking trains, we've expanded seat selection across more carriers, letting you lock in the right seat for yourself or for your entire team right from Navan.
And finally, rebooking a hotel you love is now even easier. We show your full stay history for any property so you can find that favorite and book it again in seconds.

Let's talk about one of the biggest headaches for finance teams: recovering funds for out-of-policy or personal spend on corporate cards. It's a manual process of chasing employees and running messy payroll deductions.

We've solved this problem for Navan cards, but the challenge remained for other linked corporate cards, until now. Navan Connect, which lets you extend the benefits of our expense solution to the cards of your choice, now supports repayments.
This means employees can repay personal spend on any connected cards right from Navan.
For finance teams, this means the funds are recovered and reconciled in one clean step.
Everything you saw today is another step forward in our core mission: making travel easy for every frequent traveler. This is what drives us, and we're just getting started. See you next time.
Why do I use Navan? No one asked you!
It makes managing business travel spend so freaking easy.
With Navan, employees book in-policy flights, hotels, cars, and more while I stay in control of our budget.
Ooh la la. Do you mind? Sorry.
I set my company's travel policy once, and now every employee sees what they can and can't book.
I see in real time what everyone's booking. Creepy.
And save time by automating approval flows and closing the books faster.
When my employees book below policy, they earn rewards for their vacations.
What does that even mean? I'm glad you asked.
Navan rewards employees towards their personal trips if they book hotels below policy. It's all funded by Navan.
Ergo, we improve our bottom line and our employees are happy.
It's nice not being the bad guy every now and then.
Also, did I mention that it's free to get started on Navan? I guess I just did.
Start managing business travel with ease. Sign up on Navan.com.
The Buddha said, it's the journey that matters, not the destination. But the Buddha never traveled for work.
He never arrived at his hotel after midnight to find that his reservation disappeared. Or spent his weekends filing expense reports.
He never had to stay a night here or get a pat down there. The Buddha never got stuck in the middle seat on a red-eye next to this guy. No wonder he was enlightened.
In business, what matters most is the connection that starts the moment you arrive. It's all about showing up and being there.
Humans use 18 different smiles, but only one reflects true happiness. And no matter how hard you squint, you'll never be able to see that smile through your screen.
With Navan, you'll see it live and in person. We'll help you get there and we've got your back if something goes wrong.
Navan is here to move people and ideas and businesses forward. That's the business we're in. The chat over coffee that changes everything business.
So let's go take the dread out of work travel and put some humanity back in business. Let's go make travel so effortless and easy that it's no longer a pain but a perk.
Let's go get the dreamers and the doers in the same room so they can work their magic. Navan. Making travel easy for every frequent traveler.
Welcome to Navan's Spring 2025 release.
I'm Rich Liu, CEO of Travel at Navan and I'm thrilled to share some of our most exciting new features.
We've made functionality more functional and personalization more personal.
For you, that means more control over travel and expense management and a stronger T&E program.
Ready? Let's go.
First up, flight bookings.
Our teams have been heads down responding to all the complex behind the scenes changes happening with content distribution.
We're optimizing our flight storefront so that when your travelers shop for flights, they can quickly scan the details and make faster decisions.
And NDC, we've become the industry leader because we've seen the savings and efficiencies it offers.
So we continue to go big on NDC with 18 live connections, now including Iberia, Breeze, and Aegean Airlines coming soon.
Next up, let's talk data.
Travel data can be unhelpful without a clear way of understanding the story it's telling.
That's why very soon we're expanding our analytics capabilities to offer clearer, more actionable insights.
Interactive dashboards and widgets will surface trends, identify savings opportunities, examine traveler behavior, and let you set real-time alerts.
No data science degree required.
Next up, mobile bookings, which were completely redesigned for flights and hotels on iOS.
This intuitive new interface guides travelers seamlessly from search to checkout with easier comparisons along the way.
And because it's just as important to manage expenses on the go, we've redesigned our iOS and Android expense experience for easier navigation.
At Navan, we've always been innovative and now we're officially integrated with Uber for Business.
All that receipt searching and submitting after an Uber ride? Gone.
Now Navan automatically matches Uber receipts to transactions and uploads them right after you ride.
It's another example of how we're driving the conversation.
And speaking of driving, we've improved our mileage tracker with more precise distance calculations and rates more closely aligned with regional regulations.
Logging distances is a breeze and Navan's automatic reclaim calculations mean employees can get reimbursed faster than ever.
We're also helping accountants increase their efficiency and the accuracy of the data they need.
Our updated accounting review page better supports accrual-based accounting by syncing reimbursements into your ERP based on the transaction date.
We've also added new filters and direct ERP syncing for more customized control and better cash flow visibility.
Plus, we've made month-end close speedier with bulk actions.
Now you can edit and apply up to 50 changes at once.
What's next for Navan? Follow us on LinkedIn and check us out at navan.com to learn more.

transcript_segments.text: All right. Hello everybody. I can't see the participants actually, but I'm being told that we have about 18 people on this call today. Nice to meet you all.
My name is Jess. I'm our Vice President of Travel and Expense. I've been with Navan for four years, and this is actually my last week before maternity leave.
And I call that out because you can probably hear the congestion and the fact that I'm out of breath. But thank you all for joining. We haven't done webinars in a little bit.
I think there was some webinar fatigue post-COVID, but we're back and we think it's a great way to share some context on what Navan's doing, what we're seeing in the travel and expense industry.
And we like to keep these short because I don't know that people can really pay attention for more than 30 minutes. So I'll actually kick us off today.
I encourage you to post questions. I will have someone that can field some of the Q&A questions. So as we're going through this, if you have questions, please post them in there
and we'll do our best to answer them as we go. For this first session of our webinar, I actually wanted to talk about fixing business travel's screenshot problem, as I call it.
I'm on hundreds of customer calls monthly, and when we talk to prospective customers, they're often telling us, 'I'm constantly getting screenshots from people.'
They're either finding cheaper rates elsewhere, they don't understand why they can't find something in platform, and so I like to call it the screenshot problem, right?
Where they're trying to book a hotel and it seems that that boutique hotel is not in their system, or they are looking for a flight and for some reason it's slightly cheaper on the United website.
Or maybe they're looking to fly to Europe and then take a train and they can't find that either.
And so really we're here to address today why the screenshot problem is happening and potentially why it's gotten worse post-COVID as well.
Before we do that, I wanted to anchor us in a couple interesting numbers. We published a report in partnership with Skift earlier this year
where we surveyed 15,000 travelers and admins to actually get their take on how compliance in their program has been post-pandemic, right? Since return to travel.
And I think a really interesting stat is that most managers in finance, in procurement, actually feel like getting their program to 75 or 90% compliance,
which was often the norm pre-COVID, has significantly declined. So coming out of COVID, 45% of them still felt like they were getting that 90% compliance they were looking for,
and we've seen that decrease to 39% this year. And this is really the first time in history, I would say, that business travelers and the actual managers agree on something when it comes to travel.
And the most common theme we've seen when we surveyed the travelers and the leaders in the business is that pretty much both of them cite that 46% of the time they're finding lower prices,
right? Between 30 and 40%, it's usually either 'I'm finding lower prices elsewhere' or 'I'm finding better inventory elsewhere.' Better inventory could mean, you know,
this one route that I couldn't find in Concur, or this one hotel that I couldn't find in Egencia or whatever online booking tool they're using.
And so really, whenever we talk to leaders, and we've actually seen a significant uptick in companies going out to market,
so in the last year alone, we saw a 70% uptick in companies actually going out to market, sometimes prematurely. You know, if they had a three or five-year contract,
they were going to market much earlier because they're really faced with this forced tradeoff, right? On the one hand, they can either decide to prioritize cost savings
and say, 'You know what? If our employees are doing the research and they're finding cheaper rates outside of the platform, let's let them book it. It'll save us money.'
But as a result of that, the negative consequence is that they lose visibility and often times it's a duty of care risk, right? You're not sure where your travelers are traveling,
and you know, I think the last few months has taught us that there's CrowdStrike outages and there's power outages in Europe and some planes are having issues.
And so, you know, on the one hand they either have to decide, do we let these employees book off-platform if it's cheaper, or are we actually taking the other extreme which is no,

we want to prioritize compliance, regardless of what you found elsewhere, we need you to book in-platform, that is our policy. And we want to drive compliance so we can keep you safe and have visibility,
but then as a result, you're overspending. So that's really where we come in and try to help businesses solution through that piece.
And I think that most people probably don't nerd out over travel as much as I do, and so I really wanted to talk through the root causes and why this is actually happening.
The first reason this is actually happening, and actually all of them boil down to the legacy travel management company infrastructure. But the first reason that you're seeing missed inventory
and you're getting those screenshots is because the legacy travel management companies rely primarily on the Global Distribution System (GDS).
So when you think about it, three or four years ago everyone, every travel management company was at parity in terms of where we actually sourced our content.

We all got content from the Global Distribution System. As technology has become more prevalent in travel and corporate travel, there are multiple different sources of inventory that can be pulled in.
And so when you're only relying on the Global Distribution System and you're a more legacy travel management company that hasn't necessarily invested in the technology to pull this content,
you're missing direct airline fares. You're not pulling that same content off the American Airlines or United website. You don't have access to low-cost carriers in Europe
like the Ryanairs and EasyJets which are really popular. It even goes as far as rail providers in Europe who build technology and have no real appetite to be on the Global Distribution System.
So the actual reason that you're getting those screenshots is because most legacy travel management companies haven't evolved to be able to be multi-provider by default
and pull in these different types of content as content becomes more democratized. The second piece is the problem of higher prices, right? You're constantly seeing those screenshots
and so yes, part of it is how inventory is sourced, but it's also actually how the GDS and that system prevents airlines and hotels from making pricing dynamic, right?
So when you think of consumer sites or airline sites, hotel and airfare is one of the most dynamically priced pieces of content, right?
I don't know that things on Amazon change prices that often or as often as airfare and hotels do. And so there's limitations with that old technology in terms of being able to pull dynamic pricing
that mimics those consumer sites. Lastly, and the two are kind of intertwined, if you think of the travel management companies, many of them were started in the 80s or 90s
and they were professional services firms, right? They built their business on human beings and they built their business on you calling agents for support.
As a result, in the early 2000s when they had to innovate and actually invest in technology, they chose to partner instead of investing in technology, right?
They partnered with that Global Distribution System and then they also partnered with online booking tools. And they never really invested in their own native in-house technology,

which today leads to that second problem which is it's a very disjointed process where if you are building a global business travel program, you probably have multiple instances of an online booking tool.
You might have one if you're lucky, but probably multiple travel management companies. These systems don't speak to each other and also really there's very little incentive
for the online booking tool and those companies and the travel management companies to work together. The agency would prefer that you continue to call because that is their business.
Are we getting any questions so far before I touch into Navan? I'm going to take that as a no. No questions just yet, but everyone is encouraged to drop anything they'd like
to get answered into the Q&A box. Amazing. And so lastly, before we talk about how Navan can help the problem, these off-platform bookings,
the screenshot problem that has become so prevalent post-COVID, is actually quite problematic, right? It leads to blind spots and duty of care gaps.
So if we have any anyone that's on the physical security team or security team more broadly, you're probably thinking about that piece. If we have any finance leaders on the call, right?
It's very difficult when people are finding content outside of the system to drive compliance blindly, right? And tell them that they must book in app.
It also leads to just untracked spend and lost savings because they're not being governed by policy when they book outside.

And then lastly on the back end, you're manually reconciling a lot of that data and you really don't have visibility into that travel spend until it's reimbursed or you know submitted for reimbursement
30, 60 days later. So that's really what we set out to solve. And so when these companies are going to market, we usually see pretty common themes in terms of what they're looking for.

They're looking for more content and better pricing, right? They want to know that they have a future-proof partner that is going to give them access to better content but also the ability to continue,
right? To pull content as it shows up. You know I'll give you an example, Navan has a very strong offering in India. Very few Indian carriers and providers are actually on the GDS, right?
We have to go and connect to them directly. But program owners want more content and better pricing. They want an intuitive booking experience for their travelers.
The reality is the systems you're providing them today have just evolved, right? Whether it's Zoom like we are on today or a DocuSign or whatever else it is,

like these people need an intuitive experience when they're actually on the road that is also mobile friendly. And then lastly, they just want to be able to drive higher adoption and increase employee efficiency.
Many companies have had to reduce their workforce and so it's becoming more important now than ever to ensure that your workforce is actually extremely efficient.
All right, so who is Navan? I have no idea how many of you actually know our business, so if this is repetitive, you'll have to hear it again. But Navan is 10 years old.
We're the only fully native travel and expense management platform. And what I mean by that is from day one, 10 years ago, we set out to build an all-in-one travel and expense platform.
Travel is a company's largest expenditure. We always felt that it made sense to actually build the infrastructure in the back end to be a native travel and expense platform.
I share that because most of our competitors out there today are not natively built as a travel and expense management platform. It's been put together and added on via acquisition, right?
And so the way those systems speak to each other, the way data feeds from one part of the system to the other is very different when you've built it natively from the ground up
as opposed to connecting these systems and white labeling them via acquisition. Navan today has 12,000 customers. We are the fourth largest travel management company and we have 61 offices globally.
So we've grown extremely rapidly in the last 10 years. At this stage, we support customers across every vertical. Be it financial services, tech, manufacturing, CPG,
we have a pretty wide array of customers that also range in shapes and sizes, right? So we support Unilever or Jones Lang LaSalle, right?
Massive real estate company across their 100,000 employees. But then we also support, you know, the smaller more nimble companies that are looking to grow, whether it's Instacart or DoorDash and etc.
So at this point we have, I would say we're at that sweet spot of being mature as a company, we know how to launch travel and expense quickly and efficiently, but because we're still founder-led,
we've kept that same level of agility when it comes to how fast we innovate the product. And in fact, close to 30% of our revenue is still very much invested in R&D
so we can keep pushing the boundaries of where our product is going. So in the simplest of terms, what does Navan do? We're an all-in-one platform.
We were always started to be multi-provider by default, meaning we never wanted to build our entire business around the Global Distribution System.
We built the infrastructure to be able to pull content from anywhere, be it direct connections, low-cost carriers, rail providers, cars, hotels, whatever it might be, we ingest it all.
We from the get-go wanted to own the consumer experience, both on the travel and expense side. We felt that it was paramount to obsess over the user and own the actual experience ourselves.
And so, you know, when you think of the user, it's actually not just the traveler. It's also the admins on the back end, right? How do we ensure that reporting is real-time?
How can managers access their own content without needing to ping accounting for an end-of-month report? So we've been maniacally focused on that consumer experience.
We also set out to help companies to proactively manage spend, right? So when you shift gears slightly on the expense side, we felt that expense management was too reactive of a process
and it needed to become a proactive process. And so what we've done is build the connections so that enterprises can bring their own card program and we can embed policies on those cards
to allow you to essentially set policy, right? And dictate what people are spending on proactively as opposed to reactively when they submit an expense report 30 or 60 days later.
And then lastly, a big thing that differentiates us is just transparent pricing, right? So I've talked a lot about the technology today, but we are of course a full-blown travel management company
with 64 offices globally. There are also human beings on the back end. What we didn't want to do is follow suit with the legacy industry of having a laundry list of fees
and almost disincentivizing travelers from calling support when they need to. So from the get-go we set out to create very clear and transparent pricing so that finance and procurement leaders
can essentially forecast how much they're going to spend on travel fees and expense fees every single year. And I got a question from someone, so before I touch on Zuora,
we connect with all the major ERP systems: Workday, SAP, Oracle, NetSuite, whatever it might be. And so I would definitely encourage you to set up time if you want to speak to our team,
but we would connect via API to whatever ERP system you're using at this point. All right, keep the questions coming. Really, this is one customer story but there's many anecdotes we can tell.
I picked Zuora because I figured that we might have a lot of finance leaders on this call who might be familiar with Zuora or used it in the past. Zuora was one of those companies
that was growing very rapidly and when we met them, via growth, they had kind of set up different travel management companies in each region because the perception was
that we should use a different company that has actual expertise in each major region, which was actually a really common trend where it was like, you know,

we should have a TMC in Europe that is really good with Europe or we should pick the best of the best in the US. And so they were in a situation where they had a couple different travel management companies,
they had an expense system but they were connecting to so many different travel management companies that the data wasn't really flowing in and so it was really a massive effort to just think through
how do we consolidate this, right? Is one of the three better and should we go with them, or do we actually just scratch the whole thing and start fresh?
And so the key challenges that really led them to a change was they were missing content, there was a complete lack of automation in the travel booking process,

nothing was really flowing to that expense management system seamlessly, and it was a lot of back-end work for the accounting teams who were having to manually process and review and audit every single expense report.
And I think the biggest differentiator for Navan here was our global scope, the fact that we were all in one, but more importantly, our time to value, right?
So we were able to launch them sub-60 days globally for travel and expense, right? And so part of our strength and agility is also how quickly we can launch customers.

This is kind of a systemic problem that a lot of companies have felt, like the screenshot problem has existed for a few years but it seems daunting to change a system that touches every employee in the business.

And so we really pride ourselves on being able to launch a customer, you know, if they're smaller within 30 days, and we have launched customers like Unilever in sub-90 days globally across all of their different offices.
So keep that in mind, it tends to be one of the highest visibility but low impact projects that a finance and procurement team can work on. All right, I think I saw two more questions pop up.
Ooh, I love that question. The platform is obviously top-tier, what's coming to Navan that gets you very excited? Yes, so two things.
If any of you do follow our business, you will know that our co-founder and CTO Elon has been at the forefront of Agentic AI. So yes, of course we will remain a human business,
you can't be a TMC without having agents in the back end that are supporting travelers, but what will allow Navan to continue to scale at this pace is that our Agentic AI,
our AI agent Ava, today is handling 50% of our support requests. So it's really allowing our real human agents to focus on the more complex requests and the rest is handled by our AI.
And so taking that a step farther, Elon our CTO believes that user experience as we know it really hasn't been disrupted in years, right?
If you think about even just the shift to ChatGPT or how we're having a more conversational discussion with technology, travel should be no different.
And so we're going to be launching something very exciting soon that is more related to user experience and should really allow travelers to essentially speak to an AI assistant.

There's no reason you shouldn't be able to tell them 'Hey, you saw it on my calendar I have a big meeting in New York, organize my trip,' right? And it's more of a conversation than it is you clicking through buttons.
All right, hopefully that answers your question. I can't see any faces which is very, very odd. I don't know if people are bored and off-camera or if they're actually engaged.
The other question I got was can you walk us through how Navan improves the day-to-day experience for employees? Yes, great question. So on the travel side today,
most employees are what we call cross-shopping. So they no longer trust Concur, so what they're doing before they book a trip is they go and they do a bunch of research,
they find a trip that they like, and then they try to mimic that in the Concur system. What we've seen when they move over to Navan is a 90% reduction in that cross-shopping that they do.
They then go book their trip, and the biggest difference is that very little of that trip requires any agent's assistance. So 95% of our trip bookings
and the actual trip completion does not require you calling a live agent, which is not the case with legacy agencies. Travelers have to call agents if they need to apply an unused ticket,
they have to call agents if they want to make a change to their trip, all of that is done self-service in Navan and especially post-pandemic, the feedback we get from travelers is
'Well I just let that unused ticket expire because I wasn't going to be on hold for an hour trying to use that ticket to book my trip.' So on the travel side it's the self-service piece.
Because it's connected to expense, what it also does for those travelers is that the flight receipt and flight details flow automatically into Navan and that expense is just auto-expensed for them,
they don't have to touch it. And then generally speaking as well on the expense side, what we're trying to do is remove the need for expense reports.
So because the finance team is embedding policies on their cards and because we have all that card data and we have their travel booking data, we know if they're on a trip or not on a trip.

So we know that they're allowed to spend on meals for example. So all of those expenses would be automatically approved, especially if they're under $75, because they're on a trip they have a per diem they're allowed to spend.
So the whole idea is how much can we automate that experience for travelers and how much can we remove the need to actually speak to human beings when you're on a trip.
So hopefully that answers your question, but I would very much encourage you to just take a demo and look at the actual system yourself. Can you speak on the security around AI?
Yes, at a high level I can. You know we're SOC 2 compliant, every major security clearance we've needed we've gotten, I really should have our CISO here.
Of course we provide single sign-on. When it comes to AI, your data is completely de-identified, we're not using company data to train the model, so none of your data actually makes it.
And we're using OpenAI's LLM to train our AI. I think we have a lot of that information on our website, but if not I encourage you again through our website to just request more information
and we can send you some of that. Last question, I feel like you and I need to do a solo call after this. What kind of real-time expense data or dashboards are available
to manager and finance teams? A lot. So I would say that's really our strength. There's pre-built dashboards, we have an API so you could feed it into your BI tool
and more importantly, we've actually partnered with ThoughtSpot to create advanced analytics so that essentially managers who perhaps aren't in finance, right?
So I'm thinking of like revenue leaders in the business, who might want to do a specific query, could go in there and similar to ChatGPT say, 'You know, I'm planning a sales kickoff

and I want to know how much we spent on sales kickoff the last three years,' right? And it's becoming much more conversational where it can then build that dashboard for them. So everything is real-time
and we have standard reports that break down, you know, how much the business is spending within each one of your major general ledger categories, how that compares month-over-month,
we have some peer data in there as well that's anonymized. So yeah, I would encourage you to take a look at it. Amazing. I don't want to keep people over the 30-minute mark,
but please go to our website, schedule a meeting if helpful. Hopefully we can speak about your business one-on-one and really, really understand what your challenges are.
And next time you get a screenshot from an angry traveler, now you know why. Thank you everybody.

243b6d20e1ab.filename: On-demand： Savings from managed, high-adoption travel programs.mp4

transcript_segments.text: Let's get started. So welcome everybody to our webinar today discussing savings from managed high-adoption travel programs.
Today we're going to discuss research conducted by Euromonitor in our partnership with Navan that did a deep dive into the global business travel sector.

This is going to include an estimation of the total addressable market for global business travel, B2B survey results on businesses travel outlooks for the next five years, and a comparison between the profiles of managed versus unmanaged companies.
Following a recap of the research, we'll be having a discussion around the implications of the research in managed high-adoption travel programs for businesses.
From the Euromonitor team, we have Christopher Quintos and myself, Sarah Sanders.

Chris is a senior consulting manager on Euromonitor's North America consulting team. For this research specifically, Chris helped lead the estimations for the total addressable market for the global business travel market.

And I'm a senior consultant on Euromonitor's North America consulting team. I specialize in consumer insights and I specifically worked on the B2B survey piece of this research partnership that we'll go into depth and cover shortly.
Finally, from the Navan team, we have Amy Butte. Amy is CFO of business travel and expense management firm Navan, an experienced finance leader.

Amy is an advisor to high-growth companies and corporates and previously was CFO at New York Stock Exchange. Looking forward to speaking with you, Amy, about what these research findings mean for businesses.
I love some good data, Sarah, so thank you. Looking forward to it.
Okay, so without further ado, we'll jump into the research.
Euromonitor's research partnership with Navan included sizing the addressable market, forecasting growth, and understanding those key drivers of market development.

The methodology combined with a top-down and bottom-up approach that leverages sources including Euromonitor's own proprietary Passport database, secondary sources, and a custom B2B survey that I mentioned conducted across nine markets, and finally interviews with 11 industry experts from across the world.
Our goal with this approach was to arrive at a holistic view of the global market, taking key regional factors into account before arriving at one total global view.

Today we'll talk about the outcomes of the study, including the total addressable market or TAM that was estimated for global business travel as well as the insights from the B2B survey on annual number of business trips, average spend per trip, anticipated changes in cost to businesses, and how those can differ across segments such as managed, so those who use a travel management system, and unmanaged, those who do not.
The survey that I mentioned was a B2B survey that reached a total sample of 756 respondents across nine markets.
This was fielded from March to April of this year and the countries in the survey were determined by selecting the largest geographic markets for business travel.

For example, according to our research, we know that North America accounts for around 25% of the global total addressable market for business travel in 2024. So the US and Canada were important markets for us to target in our survey.
So this is just an overview of that sample.
So diving into our key takeaways from the research, we'll start with our global business travel spend estimates.
Euromonitor estimates that in 2024, the global business travel spend is $2.1 trillion and that will increase by $800 billion to $2.9 trillion in 2029.
We know that the global business travel market reached its peak in 2019 before the COVID-19 pandemic, which we know caused a global slowdown in business travel.
However, a really key piece of our research indicated that global business travel is actually expected to surpass pre-pandemic spending levels this year.

And when we begin to look at what is driving that total addressable market, from the surveyed businesses, 85% of them actually anticipate their business travel expenditure to increase over the next five years.
That is 85% from our global survey, meaning that globally the vast majority of businesses are actually anticipating a spending increase over the next five years.
And there are multiple drivers of this anticipated expenditure increase.

The primary drivers are an anticipated increase in travel fare costs, such as plane and rail tickets, with 63% of respondents citing that as a driver for anticipated cost increases, as well as increase in accommodation costs.
Then general business growth and company expansion. Nearly half of respondents anticipated an increase in travel frequency.

This shows us that companies are anticipating spending more on travel over the next five years from both price increases from airlines and hotels, while also anticipating positive business growth that will be increasing headcount, numbers of trips, numbers of clients, and the number of employees traveling and also their travel frequency.
So although travel is becoming more expensive, businesses are not actually anticipating that to translate into an overall reduction in travel.
I'll pass it over to Chris to dive more into our data. Thank you, Sarah.

Yeah, so part of our approach in forecasting the total addressable market for global business travel was estimating the current and forecast average business trip costs, both at a market level and as a global average.

Our research confirmed our survey respondents' expectation that average business trip costs are likely to rise over the next few years, driven both by growth in prices as well as longer trips and farther destinations.
For example, Canada had the highest average trip cost in 2024 based on our research, which was estimated at about $2,400 per trip.
However, trip costs for Canadian businesses are forecast to increase slowly at about 0.8% per year to about $2,500 US dollars by 2029.
Comparatively, trip costs for US businesses are expected to grow by about 1.2% per year to over $1,800 US dollars per trip by 2029.
Trip costs are expected to grow the most for companies that have a higher share of international trips, such as those based in Europe or countries like Singapore.

As we can see from this chart, the average trip cost in Singapore is expected to grow from around $1,400 per trip in 2024 to nearly $1,800 per trip in 2029, averaging out to an annual growth rate of about 4.8% per year.

While the rising cost per trip is a major driver of global business travel spend, it's the expected growth in the number of business trips that is contributing most to the 2029 forecast total addressable market for business travel.

When looking at the number of round-trip business trips globally, according to Euromonitor's Passport database, we anticipate that the total number of business trips to increase from 3.7 billion in 2024 to 5.6 billion in 2029. That's a growth rate of about 8.8% per year.

Just a quick note, the historical estimate for business trips from Euromonitor's Passport database is primarily sourced from the UN World Tourism Organization and forecasts are modeled by Euromonitor's data engineering and travel research teams.
So looking at the composition of domestic versus international trips, we estimate that domestic trips will drive growth and account for nearly 90% of all business trips by 2029.

Finally, while trips that include air travel are expected to account for less than 15% of total business trips by 2029, the growth in the number of flights is still expected to outpace the anticipated rise in costs of airfare over that time period.
All this of course is assuming a baseline scenario of normality over the next four to five years.

Those that doubt growth in business travel will point to the pandemic and resulting remote or hybrid work, or to current geopolitical factors like trade barriers or regional conflicts as reasons why business travel should actually or likely fall.

Yet, as the chart on the right shows, survey respondents from our research indicated that client visits and travel to other offices are the top reasons for business travel, reinforcing how face time with both customers and other employees remain essential for business growth and operational effectiveness.
So now we turn to the differences in business travel between companies with a travel management system, which we refer to as managed, and those without, which we refer to as unmanaged.
When we refer to companies as unmanaged, it doesn't mean that these companies aren't traveling. Rather, it means that they are not currently using a travel management system.
Therefore, their travel is unmanaged as opposed to a company who uses a travel management system, like Navan or other systems, to manage their travel.
Our research estimates that in 2024, about 65% of total global business travel spend was made by unmanaged companies.
That share is expected to grow slightly to about 67% of global business travel spend by 2029.
Even among managed companies, leakage, or business travel booked outside of their travel management systems, is estimated to account for about 10% of total global business travel spend.

Or put another way, about 30% of managed companies' business travel that should be booked through their travel management system are instead purchased outside of it, often by employees who later submit for reimbursement.
Adoption accounts for the remainder of that managed business travel spend and it's defined as travel properly booked through a company's travel management system.

So diving deeper into leakage, which is travel booked outside of the travel management system, we estimate that the global travel spend attributed to leakage in 2024 was about $112 billion US dollars.

If the share of managed travel that is booked outside of travel management systems remains the same as in 2024, then leakage is anticipated to grow over the next five years to about $147 billion dollars. That's estimated at about an annual growth rate of about 5.6%.
So if unmanaged companies account for such a high share of global business travel spend, the logical next question is who are they?
Based on our B2B survey, over half of unmanaged companies have 200 employees or fewer, compared to managed companies which predictably are overrepresented by larger companies.
Similarly, a smaller share of business trips booked by unmanaged companies are international trips compared to those by managed companies: 26% for unmanaged, 33% for managed.
This is also intuitive given that most multinational companies have already adopted a travel management system.
However, the percentage share of employees who travel for business at unmanaged companies is not significantly lower than that of managed companies, estimated at 43% versus 51% based on the survey.
Why is this statistic important? Yes, there are typically fewer employees at an average unmanaged company, but it is not a select few at these companies who are traveling.

So at these unmanaged companies, somebody is likely responsible for managing expense reporting and reimbursements across multiple employees, as well as enforcing travel policies in order to keep costs low.

Finally, client visits or trade shows overindex for unmanaged companies as reasons for business travel, highlighting the in-person emphasis on meeting customers and or generating leads or suppliers for these unmanaged companies.
Comparatively, reasons for business trips are a lot more diverse for managed companies and include visits to other offices, sales or marketing events, and training and development.

Finally, when taking a look at business travel costs of managed versus unmanaged companies, our research found that on average, lodging accounts for 11 percentage points more of an unmanaged business's travel expenditure compared to managed companies' annual spend on lodging.
And airfare accounted for four percentage points more for unmanaged companies versus managed companies.
These data points highlight how much more exposed unmanaged companies' business travel budgets are to lodging and airfare prices compared to those of managed companies.
This also relates to leakage, given that 10% of global business travel spend in 2024 was booked outside of a travel management system.
That leakage spend would also be exposed to the higher prices seen by unmanaged companies, even though these companies experiencing leakage are already working with a travel management system.
And now I'll turn it over to Sarah and Amy for some questions.
Thanks, Chris. So what do these findings mean for businesses? So now I'd like to welcome Amy Butte, Navan CFO. Welcome, Amy.
Thank you, Sarah. It was so great to work with you and Chris and the Euromonitor team.
And you know this data—you know I love data—but there were some really surprising results.
And it was great to see, if you will, things we thought we were seeing in the business prove true through the data that you were able to uncover through your research.

Definitely. And thinking back on working on this research, one of the most surprising findings for me was that despite the rise of remote and hybrid working and even with these higher travel costs, companies are actually forecasted to travel more in the future. Why do you think that is?
Well, on a personal level, we just came back from an executive team offsite and I can say that we were able to get so much done.

We're a global company, to be able to connect with my colleagues and have so many conversations in a short period of time in a personal way that you can see that smile, that laugh, that frown, whatever it might be, it really made a difference.
I also know as a board member of companies that are partially virtual how important it is for them as well to bring people together in pods. So on a personal level I see it.
From a business standpoint for Navan relative to our customers, you know the Euromonitor forecast really validates that travel is a powerful catalyst for growth for businesses on a global basis.
You know in an increasingly digital world, the value of in-person connections has actually gone up and we see that in the data.
Meetings build that trust with a client or a colleague and allow teams to solve complex problems.
You know, and what's really fascinating is we also launched our Navan's business travel index recently which showed that business trip bookings, air and lodging, increased 15% year over year.
Another signal that companies are choosing to deploy resources for these in-person connections.
You know, I would say it's interesting the Euromonitor data almost called the news ahead of time. We're now seeing airlines talking about how they are raising prices.

But even though we're seeing that play out in the news like you anticipated we would, we're also seeing that validation that—and I see it as a CFO—business travel isn't just an expense, it's really an investment and it's an important part of the overall budget.
Definitely. And as we're seeing costs increase for travel, another surprising stat for us was that how such a large share, nearly two-thirds of business travel, remains unmanaged.

So that's a significant proportion of the global spending, especially when our research is showing clear savings for managed companies and clear differences in cost structure between those that are using a travel management company and those that are not.
So what do you think is behind so few businesses working with a travel management company for corporate travel?
Okay, but by the way, that data is crazy, right? The data is saying that companies that choose not to work with a provider pay 11% more in lodging and 4% more in air.
And so the question is are they choosing not to do that or do they feel like a managed platform is not accessible to them?
And I think that's really the difference between what I would call traditional travel versus modern travel.
Right. Traditional travel management companies are clearly failing a large percentage of our economy.
Those businesses that are traditionally smaller, but even businesses that don't think it's accessible because of the cost or the perception or it's not good to use because employees don't like it.

I was actually in a meeting yesterday with a group of people and the person across from me even admitted, like, I never book using my company's system, I always do it on... Leakage. Right, right. Massive, massive leakage.
So the question is why do we think we can do it or why do we think there's a better way?
You know, at Navan, making travel easier for every frequent traveler is our mission.
We don't differentiate whether you come from a company that's managed or unmanaged, we differentiate on the fact that you travel for business.

And that's an important thing to do. It's important to our economy, it's important to your business, and it's important to your customers and it's important to your employees and your colleagues. And that's important.
So why can we do it differently? It's really a function of technology.

Right. We are able to leverage basically APIs for content, AI and machine learning to make sure that people can see that content in a way that your favorite airline, your favorite hotel, your favorite time of flight, all pops up.
And then we can also do it in a consumer-grade interface.
And so those combinations in a way that's economically efficient for us and also economically efficient for the user or the customer means it's really a win-win-win.
And I just don't think traditional players who are still using the phone or just using email are really serving the frequent traveler. And we're seeing that in your data. It's a large percentage.
Yeah, absolutely. And we see that in our data that, as you mentioned, the shocking stats of 11% more on lodging, 4% more on flights, that they're spending more unmanaged companies are than managed.

So why do you think those that are not using are spending more? Like what are the driving factors behind those? Because assuming maybe an employee goes off their platform to book and they think that maybe there'll be more options, so those that are not using, why are they still spending more in the end?
Well, you know the old adage, if you can't measure it, you can't manage it. And I think a lot of unmanaged companies have no mechanism to enforce policy or optimize spending. Right?

They can only see an out-of-policy expense after the fact when it's too late. Where a managed platform, particularly one that's real-time like Navan, can prevent that overspending from ever happening.
You literally get a pop-up that says this is out of policy if you try to do it on our platform.
And our dynamic policy feature also allows for automated and flexible travel rules.
Like for example, have you ever tried to get a hotel room in San Francisco during Dreamforce? It's impossible, right? So you need a dynamic policy that works with how people travel.

We also think that deep supplier relationships allow modern TMCs to offer optimal and dynamic prices across a wide content base. Many companies, even in a managed world, really only get one choice, whether it's for that hotel or a certain number.
You know, at Navan, we're really invested in a multi-source strategy, which gives us access to critical channels to source the fares at highly competitive prices for customers.

So for example, when you try to book a hotel room, we can give you three choices. And depending on whether you want it to be refundable, whether you want your points or you don't want your points, whether you want some of our travel rewards that we offer, you can—we can let the user make that decision while still benefiting the customer to save money.
Now let's also not forget, which wasn't in the data, how much time most employees have to spend or EAs have to spend to book a trip.
I think there's some general data out there that says an average time to book a trip is about 45 minutes.

You know, we can do it in about 7 to 8 minutes on average. And so we're constantly able to save customers money in their travel budget, and we're also able to save users time, which in many ways is the equivalent of money, especially if you're in a sales function.
Absolutely. And when we did conduct our research, in order to be comprehensive, we looked at companies of varying sizes, so from small and medium companies all the way to large multinationals.
And then apart from size, we looked at companies across all these industries.

And so we know that there are varying levels of travel, whether it's only domestic, international, client visits, off-sites like you mentioned, conferences, trainings, and more. So with this level of varying needs, like how can all companies benefit from the addition of a TMC?
Right, like the worst thing that you can do as a CFO or a finance professional is one, see data too late to act on, right?
And unmanaged when it's on paper or if it's coming from multiple systems, you can't see it that day or that week or that month, and so it makes it really hard to act on.

You know, two, it's really important—most people don't know this, I didn't know this until I came from Navan—there's actually a duty of care that companies have when their companies travel, when their employees travel.
Companies are supposed to know where they are at all times, so if a plane goes down, you know about it. And how do you do that if somebody has leaked and booked their own travel and you don't know?

And third, you know, this is my finance hat, you need to audit this, right? And so that reconciliation is really important. And do you want your team spending hours at the end of the month doing manual reconciliation or can you automate that?

You know, we live in a very competitive world, and so I think anything a finance leader can do to bring in modern technology to automate, increase efficiency, as well as just make sure you do a better job for your employees and you leverage the company to a higher return on investment, those are all really important things.

Absolutely. Appreciated it, Amy, and appreciate everyone for coming. And if you've sent questions through related to the research, the data, our discussion, we'll take a look at them and get back to you after the webinar. But appreciate everyone's time and the discussion, Amy. Thank you. No, thanks, and thanks to the Euromonitor team. What a great partnership.
Welcome to Navan, the global travel and expense solution loved by CFOs and employees alike.
